data: [★], [no gloss] (A), ša-ga-lum, /ṯaḳālum/, ¶‘to weigh’ (v). See the discussion sub. VE 409a.
[no gloss] A4-6, [no gloss] B, [no gloss] AW; see the discussion sub VE 877.
a-ša-ḫa-bu3 (O), [no gloss] (R); Hajouz no. 147; ¶'Rougue man', Akk. isḫappu (CAD I-J [1960], s.v., 189); Civil, 'Bilingualism' (1984).

gu2-du-gu2-du-wu-um (u). Hajouz no. 689 ¶'One that is always jumping'; maybe a loan from Sum. gud2, gu4-ud, 'to jump', Civil, 'Bilingualism' (1984), 92. Note that MEE 4 assigns the term to the bilingual excerpt u (MEE 4, 95), but it is attested in MEE 4, 96 (TM.75.G.10018) labelled by Pettinato as excerpt v. However, the text can be classified as a bilingual list of animals, rather than an excerpt of the VE. The entry should thus be removed as it does not present any direct connection to any manuscript of the VE.

za-bi2-tum (AZ), ša-ma-ak-tum (d); ¶'tavern-keeper; prostitute'; Steinkeller, 'Prostitutes' (2022), 3 and n7: glosses can be normalized sābītum ('tavern-keeper') and šamkatum / šamḫatum ('prostitute'). See also Archi, 'Kamiš' (2020), 12n21, who reads za-ne-tum, from √zny/w. See Hajouz no. 906 (√šmk) and Hajouz no. 1080 (√zny). See also VE 1412'b.
za-bi2-tum (d); ¶'tavern-keeper'; Steinkeller, 'Prostitutes' (2022), 3: gloss can be normalized sābītum, 'tavern-keeper'. See Hajouz no. 1080 (√zny). See the comment sub VE 1412'a.

★, [no gloss] (A, B, AK); ¶'Lapis lazuli'. On this semi-precious stone, see Pasquali, Lessico (2005), 9. In the administrative record, the term is also attested as za-gin3 or gin3(-gin3). Civil, 'Early History' (1987), 145, observes that the word is a loan from an unknown language, and probably means 'blue (stone)'.
★, [x]-⸢x⸣-lu-um (A₄), za-bi2-lu-um (O), za-ba-lu SAG (K). On the gloss of source K see the comment in VE 255.

★, a-bar-tum (AD), [no gloss] (B₁₀); Hajouz no. 2: from √ʾbr, ¶'eagle' or ¶'feather', see also Bonechi, 'Noms d'oiseaux à Ébla' (2000); other translations include '(a kind of headgear)', see Archi, 'Minima eblaitica 8' (1988). See Hajouz, 32-33 for a detailed discussion.

★, bu3-gu2-um (s), [no gloss] (A4-5, ak); ¶'monkey', also normalized kiri3-ma. Archi (NABU 2022/80, 176), recently wrote that excerpt s (M 4, 93) presents the gloss (omitted in MEE 4); Catagnoti, NABU 1989/31.

★, dal-da-gi-lum (A2, B2, C) ti-da-bir5-lum (i), [no gloss] (K); Hajouz no. 894. ¶'Instruction, order' (DDCLT: Ebla, Acrographic List A, obv.VI:3). The two glosses come from roots √śkr and √dbr repsectively (Conti, MisEb 3 [1990], 95–96). Normalized as taśtakīrum and teddanbērum (Bonechi, QdL 16 [2006], 92). inim-di-inim-di = 'Disposizioni, ordini' (Catagnoti and Fronzaroli, ARET XVIII [2020], 136, s.v.; Catagnoti and Fronzaroli, ARET XVI [2010], 241, s.v.

★, gu-da-nu-um (A, B); ¶'(a kind of garment)'; a second gloss gu-da-num is quoted as belonging to manuscript C. See Catagnoti and Fronzaroli, ARET XVI (2010), 130, who connects the gloss to √qtn, 'to be thin' (after Pettinato, MEE 2 [1980], 128). Samir (ARET XIX [2019], 233) and Archi (ARET XIV [2023]) also connect the gloss to Akk. qutānu/kutānu.
★, sa-na-tum (A), sa-na-du-um (O); ¶ 'Acacia', interpreted as šanṭum, cfr. Akk. šamṭu. Used to cure cattle (see MEE 3 69 = TM.75.G.1645). Catagnoti, 'Lessico dei vegetali' (2018).

★, su-mu-tum (A₁), [su-mu-t]um (B₈); /šummuttum/, ¶‘tethering rope’. Hajouz no. 908. Krebernik, 'Mesopotamian Myths' (1992), 136, suggests a reading šamanx of the Sumerian lemma, a word attested in ARET V 7 = TM.75.G.2660+. Cfr. Akkadian šummannu. See also Fronzaroli, 'Divinazione' (1997), 18; Sjöberg, 'Selected Entries I' (2003), 529-530 with bibliography; Kogan and Krebernik, 'Eblaite' (2021), 832. See also VE 483.
★, u-bux-lum (AD), [no gloss] (A₄, B); Hajouz no. 1: ¶'strenght', from √ʾbr, 'to be strong'
★, u3-ba-su-um (C), [no gloss] (A₂, L); Hajouz no. 3: ¶'fraud', from √ʾbš. For a different interpretation ('to sleep'), see D'Agostino, Sistema verbale (1990), 78.

★, wa-za-nu-um (A), wa-za-num2 (B), ša-gi-lum (V); ¶'weigher'; see also Akk. šaqālu, Ar. wazānum, 'to weigh'; the gloss ša-gi-lum can be connected to a Proto-Semitic root √ṯḳl, ṯaḳilum, 'heavy' (see also VE 418 ša-ga-lum, /ṯaḳālum/, ‘to weigh’). A possible interpretation of the first two glosses is wazzānum, 'weigher', see Bonechi, 'Nomi di professione' (2006), 87. See also DUL3, s.v. mzn, 599-600, 'weight'; Fronzaroli, 'Eblaic Lexicon' (1984), 149 and 152; Conti, 'Sillabario' 1990, 13; . For the reading šakil(a)x o šakal(a)x of the Sumerian lemma, see Bonechi, 'Nomi di professione' (2006), 82-83. Note that Michalowski suggested that √ṯḳl and √wzn are variants of the same root ('Shekel and the Vizier' [1990], 6).

gi-ba-um (A₁, B, h) ¶'exquisite edible commodity', see Bonechi, 'Thorny Problems' (2016), 57-58n182; ¶'shrimp', see Winters, 'Negotiating Exchange (2019)', 350-51; ¶'locusts', see Catagnoti and Fronzaroli, ARET XVIII (2020), 10, Militarev and Kogan , SED II (2005), 112 s.v. with bibliography; ¶'foodstuff', see Steinkeller, 'International trade' (2021), 181. Variants of this spelling are found in the administrative record (ki-ba-im, ku₃-ba-um, gi-ba-um).
The entry should be removed. Collation by Pelio Fronzaroli ('Veterinary Prescription [2005], 90n8) reveals that source K reads sag–sum / za-ba-lu SAG, and therefore refers to VE 254.
ʾa3-a-um (BG), [no gloss] (BB); Krebernik, 'Syllables' (2018), 170, √ḥll, ¶'to clean, to wash'
